item.title: Mercurial and Git
item.description: Mercurial and Git are both used for version control. Both Mercurial (Hg) and Git are popular distributed version control systems (DVCS), but they have some key differences in their approach: Branching Model: Mercurial: Employs a centralized branching model, meaning each branch has its own separate directory. Switching branches involves changing directories. This can be simpler for beginners but less flexible for complex workflows. Git: Uses a decentralized branching model, where all branches exist within the same repository.

item.title: commitment and promise
item.description: TLDR A commitment holds more weight than a simple promise They do differ in how they frame the distinction: Emphasis on intent: Commitment signifies a genuine desire to fulfill the promise, suggesting sincerity and motivation. Focus on strength: Commitment implies a stronger promise than one can readily deliver highlighting its ambitious nature. Contrast with indulgence: Commitment stands against indulgence, emphasizing dedication and perseverance as key differentiators. In essence, commitments go beyond empty promises, demonstrating a willingness to put in the effort and potentially exceed expectations.

About Me Chang Wen Chen is a CAD architecture and chip design engineer, offering 5+ years of experience in both hardware design as well as software development. Products conducted including 5G modern chips, CPU with advance process nodes and automatic CAD flow development. Strong skills in back-end implementation, process in advance nodes, timing/power/area/schedule analyzing, flow automation. Excelled at integrating information and communicating.
